channel.title: Website on Ana Rebelo
channel.description: Recent content in Website on Ana Rebelo

item.title: MINEX III Certification by NIST
item.description: In collaboration with the Imprensa Nacional-Casa da Moeda (INCM), our work obtained MINEX III certification - Minutiae Interoperability Exchange - by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) of the United States (US) Department of Commerce. This certification is a test used to establish that template generation and correspondence algorithms comply with the US government’s Personal Identity Verification (PIV) program and aims to assess the quality and robustness of biometric recognition algorithms.

item.title: Incredible International Workshop on Explainable & Interpretable for Biometrics
item.description: International Workshop on Explainable & Interpretable Artificial Intelligence for Biometrics at WACV The xAI4Biometrics Workshop at WACV 2021 aims at promoting a better understanding, through explainability and interpretability, of currently common and accepted practices in several and varied applications of biometrics. These applications, in scenarios comprising identity verification for access/border control, watching lists surveillance, anti-spoofing measures embedded in biometric recognition systems, forensic applications, among many others, affect the daily life of an ever-growing population.

item.title: Best reviewer award at IJCB2020
item.description: The 2020 International Joint Conference on Biometrics (IJCB 2020) combines two major biometrics research conferences, the Biometrics Theory, Applications and Systems (BTAS) conference and the International Conference on Biometrics (ICB).

item.title: The 8th International Workshop on Biometrics and Forensics
item.description: International Workshop on Biometrics and Forensics The International Workshop on Biometrics and Forensics (IWBF) is devoted to facilitating synergies in research and development among the areas of multimedia forensics, forensic biometrics, and forensic science. IWBF 2020 is jointly organized by EAB; INESC TEC, Porto, Portugal and NTNU, Gjovik, Norway. Important dates Papers / Demos / Doctoral Consortium Submission Deadline: February 15, 2020 Conference: April 29-30, 2020 For more information please consult the official website.

item.title: Monitor in the Future of Computing Summer School.
item.description: Monitor in the GPU-Accelerated Computing workshop given by Cristiana Dinea from NVIDIA Deep Learning Institute. Check more at Future of Computing summer school website.

item.title: Creation of the SI-PSL database
item.description: Signer-Independent Portuguese Sign Language (SI-PSL) database The SI-PSL database was specially created for signer-independent evaluation purposes. It contains 31 isolated signs, representing the alphabet and the cardinal numbers 0 to 9 of the Portuguese sign language. All the signs were performed three times by a total of 11 native signers, in a free and natural signing environment, without any clothing restriction but with a slightly-controlled uniform background (see Figure below). Therefore, it clearly depicts the large inter-signer variability that exists in the manual signing process of sign languages.

item.title: Creation of the CorSiL database
item.description: A Portuguese Sign Language and Expressiveness Recognition Database The CorSiL database was created within the framework of a research project at INESC TEC, Porto, Portugal, which aimed to develop both a video-based automatic SLR system and a expressiveness analysis method of the human body during the interaction between a pair of subjects. In this manner the CorSiL database has two major components (or subsets) each one with a specific purpose:

item.title: Biometric Recognition with Portable Devices Competition
item.description: 1st Biometric Recognition with Portable Devices Competition This competition is part of ICIAR 2013 conference and the MobBIO Multimodal Database is used. The main goal of the competition is to compare different methodologies for biometric recognition using data acquired with common portable devices, such as smartphones or tablets. The team involved were: Ana F. Sequeira, Hélder Oliveira, João Monteiro and I.

item.title: Creation of the MobBIO multimodal database
item.description: The MobBIO Multimodal Database The MobBIO Multimodal Database comprises the biometric data from 105 volunteers. Each individual provided samples of face, iris and voice. The nationalities of the volunteers were mainly portuguese but also participated volunteers from U.K., Romania and Iran. The average of ages was approximately 34, being the minimum age 18 and the maximum age 69. The gender distribution was 29% females and 71% males For more information please read the following paper MobBIO: A Multimodal Database Captured with a Portable Handheld Device.
